brief_summary.textblock: Robotic Assisted Evacuation of Sub-acute and Chronic Hypertensive Cerebral Hemorrhage for Accelerating Functional Rehabilitation: a Multi-center Clinical Trial

detailed_description.textblock:
1. Research background: The existing literature is controversial about the surgical treatment of hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage, especially for the hemorrhage that is less than or equal to 30ml in the deep functional area of the brain. Many large-scale clinical studies have not shown surgery (open surgery). , Minimally invasive puncture and hemolysis). The patient's prognosis (survival rate, functional recovery) was not significantly different from conservative treatment.
2. There are shortcomings in previous studies: the intervention time, intervention methods are complicated, there are many confounding factors, and the multimodal evaluation data are lacking. Therefore, the research results are coarse and lacking in credibility.
3. The general opinion of the surgeon: Early removal of hematoma can help reduce intracranial hypertension and reduce the compression of functional fiber conduction bundles. In theory, there is a benefit. However, surgery may also have the risk of iatrogenic destruction of functional fiber bundles.
4. Our design:
1) Exclude patients in the acute phase (hematoma progressively enlarged and impaired consciousness). These patients should undergo surgery immediately. However, the personal judgment of the first-visiting doctors (Shenin and Shenwai) has a great influence, and early treatment may not be timely. The long-term prognosis has caused bias in the study. At the same time, due to the rapid course of the disease, the relevant assessment cannot be improved in the early stage, resulting in missing data.
2) For patients who choose early conservative treatment, after the hematoma enters the subacute stage, complete the relevant imaging examinations, exclude vascular malformations, and clarify the relationship between blood clots and important white matter fiber bundles, and perform robotic minimally invasive aspiration. On the one hand, it reduces the pressure of hematoma on the peripheral functional fiber bundles, while minimizing iatrogenic damage; on the other hand, it reduces the killing of peripheral nerve cells by the deposition of hemosiderin after the disintegration of red blood cells.

arm_group.description: For patients who choose early conservative treatment, after the hematoma enters the subacute stage, complete the relevant imaging examinations and perform robotic minimally invasive aspiration.
Patients who are unwilling to undergo surgery and have hemorrhage in the deep functional area of the brain within 30ml.

intervention.description: Perform robotic minimally invasive puncture and aspiration. On the one hand, it reduces the pressure of hematoma on the peripheral functional fiber bundles, while minimizing iatrogenic damage; on the other hand, it reduces the killing of peripheral nerve cells by the deposition of hemosiderin after the disintegration of red blood cells.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. The deep supratentorial intracerebral hemorrhage diagnosed by CT is calculated using the modified Tada formula or 3D reconstruction with imaging software. The volume of the hematoma is between 15-30ml
2. CTA or DSA excludes other vascular diseases such as aneurysms and arteriovenous malformations.
3. The GCS score is greater than 8 points.
4. Existence of neurological dysfunction (motor, sensory, language) clearly related to hypertensive cerebral hemorrhage
5. Age â‰¥ 18;
6. Written informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. There was limb movement disorder before the onset, which affected the function evaluation 90 days after the intervention.
2. History of known coagulation system dysfunction
3. Have a history of brain trauma, cerebral hemorrhage, and cerebral infarction in the past 3 months
4. Major surgery or trauma to other parts of the body 2 weeks before the onset.
5. Known history of immune insufficiency.
6. According to the AHA guidelines, any situation that requires surgical intervention in the early stage of the disease:
i. GCS score is less than 8 points; ii. The volume of the hematoma exceeds 50ml, and there is obvious midline bias; iii. Progressive intracranial hypertension that cannot be controlled after conservative treatment.
